nit, for these kinds of transforms, prefer to use a local variable of nlohmann::json::array, then std::move it into the final location, rather than doing the map lookup twice, similar to how you do it for the array itself.

FWIW, I really wish json had an "emplace()" method that returned a reference to the type that you emplaced, so you could do

nlohmann::json::array_t arr = json.emplace("Members", nlohmann::json::array_t());

Oh well.
Maybe one day "emplace()" will be added.  I've made the change.
Please use urlFromPieces.
Done
I keep getting a clang warning about a memory leak occurring within this function call.  I'm still investigating.
I found two different approaches for solving this.  You can see them in patchsets 22 and 24.  My guess is patchset 24 has the correct approach, but I'll leave this open for confirmation.
I look at the diff, and a see a bunch of commented out code in 22 that's missing in 24. .......  If you think you're in the right on the memory leak, I trust your judgement.

I think it's actually patchset 21 which has the first fix and 24 that has the second fix.  Patchset 22 should have the same fix as 24.  In 24 I just cleaned up the commented code that was present in 22 to make it more readable.  All of the commented code was just my previous attempts at getting a working solution.

The two approaches are how the handler argument is handled in the capture inside getSatelliteConfigs() from redfish_aggregator.hpp.  The approaches are essentially:

1) [handler{handler}]
2) [handler{std::move(handler)}]

The code is currently configured for the second option.
Both of those should work, minor preference for #2 to avoid the copy (emphasis on minor).
Cool that was my thought as well
Password is generally read-only in the spec (I'll be honest, I didn't check in this case) which would mean this needs to be null.

In the code if I use NULL instead of "" then the validator complains because that gets surfaced as

"Password": 0,

And the validator expects a string.

You're right, the spec says Password must be null in responses https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.3.pdf#page=117.  

I figured out how to expose those as null values. I reran the service validator to verify and updated the commit message with the new output.
Changed these to match the syntax used by the other route handlers.
Nit, please just use auto here.  bind_front does not produce a std::function, so this code is doing some implicit stuff that you probably want to avoid.

If I use auto then I get the same error I mention below about binding a non-const lvalue.

Do I for sure want to avoid doing the implicit stuff?  If nothing else I could always go back to using a copy inside of getSatelliteConfigs().
I'm now directly passing std::bind_front to getSatelliteConfigs().  Closing since this is no longer relevant.
std::move
I can't use std::move here.  It complains about "cannot bind non-const lvalue reference of type .... to an rvalue of type ....
I'm now directly passing std::bind_front to getSatelliteConfigs().  Closing since this is no longer relevant.
This is your problem.  You need to take this by value, because you need to take ownership of it.  Remove the & and you should be able to get rid of the copy previously.
I'm pretty sure I tried that previously and clang complained about me passing the argument by value.  Using std::move() was the only alternative I found to having to do a copy.
It didn't complain this time.  Maybe it's because this time I also included std::move in the capture of async_method_call()?  Maybe I remembered wrong?  Either way I'm marking this resolved.
long lambdas are now disallowed int the coding standard.  This came from previously, which is fine, but somethign to be aware of.
You need to pass the error back to the handler.

Alright, I should be able to make the handler take the error as an argument such that it becomes

std::function<void(
            const boost::system::error_code ec,
            const std::unordered_map<std::string, boost::urls::url>&)>& handler
Done

When we support multiple satellites the aggregation prefix may become something like <aggregationId>_<satelliteId> whereas right now it is only <aggregationId>.

We'll need to account for <aggregationId>_<satelliteId> being a local AggregationSource and <aggregationId>_<satelliteId>_<AggregationSource> being an AggregationSource from a satellite BMC.  We'll be able to derive the <aggregationId> at runtime, but we won't know <satelliteId> until after we query dbus to get the satellite configs.  We currently can't do the latter until after we have determined whether or not we need to handle the request locally on the aggregating BMC.

I don't think we need to deal with this right now.  It'd be better implemented as part of adding support for multiple satellite BMC.  Please mark this as unresolved if you should we should deal with that now as part of this patch.

We currently don't store the Name since there isn't an obvious for it in the boost::urls::url object that holds the information.  We could do something like storing it as a param "Name=<Name>" or just as the path.  Or make the object a little more generic than just boost::urls::url so that we could utilize other types of aggregation instead of just HTTP/ethernet based connections.

My preference is to leave this to its own patch (especially if we opt for option 2).
error_code shoudl be passed by const ref.
Done
by reference please.
Done
I realized you just moved code here, but lambdas over 15 lines are now banned.  This is probably ok, because it's no worse, but please keep that in mind.
Ack.  I was aware of that change and didn't know if it applied in this situation.  I can go back in a later patch and clean this up after some of the other aggregation patches get sorted out
should be array_t
Done
Please also implement the HEAD handler for this.
I added one for both AggregationSources and AggregationSource.
THis needs to return.
Done
Please just make this "Aggregation source"
Done
Can this be built with a url object instead of doing it by hand?

"sat->second" is actually already a url object.  When I previously checked I was not able to find a url method which corresponds to "scheme://host:port".  After further digging I figured out that encoded_origin() does just that.  I've made the change.
ACK.
Please do = nullptr.
Done
We currently "don't support" this, so it should be omitted.
Done

Minor nit comments.  Fix if you want.
I'll go ahead and fix them
Done
we don't support username yet?
Yup that was leftover from it being included in an earlier patchset.  Removed.
error code should always be passed by reference.
I fixed this one as well as another instance of it in this patch.
